I'm trying to understand the algorithmic implications: If I have some goo=
d genetic code that you don't have and give it to you "horizontally," i.e. =
without mating, how is that different computationally from me mating with y=
ou and having an offspring that combines all of your code with my bit of ex=
tra code?  I guess one difference is that there was no selection operation;=
 the "offspring" was created without me needing to mate.  So it seems like =
a sort of less greedy form of selection in which you can pass on your genes=
 without succeeding at finding a mate or even performing reproduction.  Yet=
 is it anything over and above less greedy evolution?  For example, would i=
t be much different if we just relaxed the criteria of selection?  I guess =
I'm not sure if the implications are really fundamental or just technical, =
that is, if it somehow changes what is possible to discover or if it just m=
eans it happens in a different way than was presumed in some cases.

ken

-=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "R" <shanemcdonaldryan@...> wrote:
>
> This is =
an interesting article.
> http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20527441.50=
0-horizontal-and-vertical-the-evolution-of-evolution.html?full=3Dtrue&print=
=3Dtrue
> 
> It talks essentially about the process that gave rise to the e=
volutionary algorithm and protein synthesis machinery.
> 
> I wonder if you=
 could use something like it to tweak or build an evolutionary algorithm?
>=
 
> What do you guys think?
>
